<e0>commit local changes to the server: </e0>right-click on the local checkout directory and select <g1>SVN Commit....</g1> The Commit window - see below opens.
<e0>commit local changes to the server: </e0>right-click on the local checkout folder and select <g1>SVN Commit....</g1> The Commit window - see below opens.
<e0>commit: </e0>once a new local version of the checked-out material is ready, it can be committed to the repository and thus made available to the rest of the team.
<e0>display all results: </e0>clearing this check box will case OmegaT show just the first occurrence of a hit, if several hits exist
<e0>in notes: </e0>search in notes to segments
<e0>in source: </e0>search in the source segments
<e0>in translations: </e0>search in the target segments
<e0>repository: </e0>the place where the shared material is saved and maintained, either on a local access network or in Internet.
<e0>search TMs</e0>: translation memories in the <f1>tm</f1> folder are included in the search.
<e0>several projects on the same subject: </e0>keep the project structure, and change source and target directories (Source = source/order1, target = target/order1 etc).
<e0>several projects on the same subject: </e0>keep the project structure, and change source and target folders (Source = source/order1, target = target/order1 etc).
<e0>several translators working on the same project:</e0> split the source files into source/Alice, source/Bob... and allocate them to team members (Alice, Bob ...).
<e0>update local files from the local repository copy</e0> - the changes received from the server repository reside within the .svn subfolder but not yet in the files and folders themselves.
<e0>user</e0>: a member of the team, collaborating on the common project.

<e0> Instant start guide:</e0> this chapter is intended as an Instant Start Guide for beginners and “tyre kickers”, showing the complete procedure from opening a new translation project through to completing the translation.
<e1>YEAR</e1> is 4-digit year, <e2>MM</e2> is a month, <e3>DD</e3> day of the month, <e4>HH</e4> and <e5>NN</e5> are hours and minutes when the previous translation memory was saved.

<l0>.txt</l0> files are automatically (<auto>) interpreted by <a1>OmegaT</a1> as being encoded in the computer's default encoding.
<l0>.utf8</l0> files are interpreted by <a1>OmegaT</a1> as being encoded in UTF-8 (an encoding that covers almost all languages in the world).

If OmegaT contains a language version which you would like to use but is not the language of your operating system, you can force OmegaT to use the desired version by changing the launch command.
If the document you are translating contains it, please do not translate the GPL (GNU Public License) or the GFDL (GNU Free Documentation License).
If you are confident that a suitable version of the JRE is already installed on your computer, you can download a version of OmegaT without the JRE.
If you install the OmegaT version even though the JRE is already installed on your computer, OmegaT's JRE will be installed separately and will not conflict with it.
If you wish to translate the OmegaT web pages, download the website localization package.
In order to install the Web start version, you must already have Java version 1.3 or later installed on your computer.
In order to run, OmegaT requires the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) to be installed on your computer.

In the /docs/ folder of the OmegaT program, create a sub-folder with the ISO code of your operating system language (rename the existing folder temporarily if it already exists), and copy the manual into this folder.

Legacy versions are older versions that have been superseded.

Linux users: most Linux distributions are supplied with a Java Runtime Environment, but some open-source implementations do not work properly with OmegaT (although this may not be immediately apparent).
Mac OS X users: the JRE is installed on Mac OS X by default; there is therefore no version for Mac OS X with the JRE.

OmegaT is a free, open-source translation memory program.
OmegaT is supplied with a comprehensive user manual.
Options > File Filters > Select "XHTML files" > Edit > Add > Then enter "*.php" in the "Source Filename Pattern" column.

Platform-specific versions of OmegaT are provided for Windows, Linux and Mac OS X. A platform-indpendent version is also available which will run on any operating system capable of running a suitable version of the Java Runtime Environment.
Please keep translations of files in their original format.
Privacy information: OmegaT Java Web Start does not save any of your information to OmegaT's web servers.
Source code packages are not required by users and are intended for developers only.
The /trunk (alpha) version reflects the very latest state of development.
The Latest version is a more recent version than the Standard version and includes new features not present in the latter.
The OmegaT website includes files in HTML and, as of 2011, PHP format.
The Standard version has usually been in use for some time and is therefore proven.
The Web Start version offers an alternative means of installing OmegaT on your computer.

As opposed to user-generated translation memories (as in the case of <a0>OmegaT</a0>) Machine translation (MT) tools use rule-based linguistic tools to create a translation of the source segment without the need for a translation memory.

As opposed to user-generated translation memories on one side (like in the case of OmegaT) or rule-based systems (usually found under the name of "machine translation" or MT in short) Google can afford a different approach: they feed the computer billions of words of text, both monolingual text in the target language, and aligned text consisting of examples of human translations between the languages.

By default, the Go To Next Untranslated Segment command (Ctrl+U) skips to the next untranslated segment, skipping propagated translations in the process.

OmegaT is a computer-assisted translation (CAT) tool.

OmegaT is a free and open source multiplatform Computer Assisted Translation tool with fuzzy matching, translation memory, keyword search, glossaries, and translation leveraging into updated projects.
OmegaT is a free multi platform Computer Aided Translation tool, with the following highlights:
OmegaT is a free translation memory application written in Java.
OmegaT is a free, open-source translation memory program.
OmegaT is a robust application.
OmegaT is able to recognize that you have done this.
OmegaT is able to store translations that are identical to the source.
OmegaT is also capable of reading glossaries in TBX, the industry-standard format for glossary files.
OmegaT is among the CAT tools for which this process can be used.

OmegaT is an "inline" translation memory application, meaning that you see only one copy of the text; segments which have already been translated appear as such, otherwise <t0/>the untranslated source text is displayed.
OmegaT is an excellent place to start, as the price is right, it is relatively easy to learn, and it runs on MAC and under Linux, as well as Windows.
OmegaT is an open-source application and project.
OmegaT is available bundled with a SUN Java JRE for Linux (Intel x86) and Windows platforms.
OmegaT is available in many different versions in order to suit a range of user requirements.
OmegaT is capable of handling the current Microsoft Office formats directly, without conversion to or from other formats.

Paragraph segmentation is advantageous in certain cases, such as highly creative or stylistic translations in which the translator may wish to change the order of entire sentences; for the majority of projects, however, sentence segmentation is a choice to be preferred, since it delivers better matches from previous translations.
Paragraph segmentation is less frequently used, but can be useful in cases of so-called "creative" texts, The rule-based segmentation is usually synonymous with sentence-based segmentation.

Plain text files
